9-27.scene_title: Meeting Stamford at the Criterion Bar
9-27.description: Dr. Watson, after deciding to change his living arrangements due to financial constraints, encounters an old acquaintance, Stamford, at the Criterion Bar in London. They recognize each other and decide to have lunch together, discussing Watson's recent hardships and his current search for affordable lodgings.
text_phrases: turning round I recognized young Stamford
asked him to lunch with me at the Holborn
we started off together in a hansom
rattled through the crowded London streets

9-27.description: During lunch at the Holborn, Watson and Stamford discuss Watson's need for new lodgings. Stamford mentions another man, Sherlock Holmes, who is also looking for a roommate to share the expenses of some nice rooms he found.
text_phrases: lunch with me at the Holborn
you are the second man today that has used that expression to me
a fellow who is working at the chemical laboratory
could not get someone to go halves with him in some nice rooms
if he really wants someone to share the rooms and the expense, I am the very man for him

28-53.description: Dr. Watson meets Sherlock Holmes for the first time in a chemical laboratory where Holmes is excitedly sharing his discovery of a new reagent for blood detection.
text_phrases: lofty chamber, lined and littered with countless bottles
Broad, low tables were scattered about, which bristled with retorts, test-tubes, and little Bunsen lamps
brownish dust was precipitated to the bottom of the glass jar

54-80.scene_title: Holmes and Watson Discuss Their Habits
54-80.description: Sherlock Holmes and Dr. John Watson discuss their personal habits and peculiarities as they consider becoming roommates.
text_phrases: pushing another one in my direction with his foot
sticking a small piece of plaster over the prick on his finger
mottled over with similar pieces of plaster

54-80.scene_title: Holmes and Watson Agree to Share Rooms
54-80.description: Sherlock Holmes and Dr. John Watson finalize their decision to share rooms at Baker Street after discussing their habits and ensuring they are compatible roommates.
text_phrases: I have my eye on a suite in Baker Street
you don’t mind the smell of strong tobacco
I generally have chemicals about, and occasionally do experiments
Do you include violin-playing in your category of rows?

54-80.description: Sherlock Holmes and Dr. John Watson move their belongings into their new shared apartment at 221B Baker Street.
text_phrases: inspected the rooms at No. 221B, Baker Street

81-93.description: The narrator reflects on his curiosity about his mysterious companion, leading to a conversation where the companion reveals his selective knowledge acquisition philosophy.
text_phrases: little mystery which hung around my companion
man’s brain originally is like a little empty attic
useless facts elbowing out the useful ones

81-93.description: The narrator lists out the areas of knowledge and ignorance of his companion, Sherlock Holmes, reflecting on the peculiarities of his expertise.
text_phrases: His ignorance was as remarkable as his knowledge
man’s brain originally is like a little empty attic
document when I had completed it

81-93.description: Sherlock Holmes plays the violin in a reflective and sometimes whimsical manner, showcasing his mood through music.
text_phrases: played in quick succession a whole series of my favourite airs

94-105.description: Sherlock Holmes receives various visitors in his sitting room, ranging from Mr. Lestrade to a fashionably dressed young girl, a seedy looking old man, and others, indicating the diverse nature of his clientele.
text_phrases: railway porter in his velveteen uniform

94-105.description: Dr. Watson finds Sherlock Holmes still at breakfast, leading to a discussion about an article Holmes wrote on deduction, which Watson initially criticizes.
text_phrases: Sherlock Holmes had not yet finished his breakfast

106-129.scene_title: Holmes and Watson Discussing in the Room
106-129.description: Sherlock Holmes and Dr. John Watson are in their shared living room, discussing Holmes' unique deductive abilities and comparing him to fictional detectives like Dupin and Lecoq.
text_phrases: Sherlock Holmes rose and lit his pipe
I walked over to the window

106-129.description: A commissionaire, formerly a sergeant of Marines, arrives at Holmes and Watson's residence with a letter for Sherlock Holmes, crossing the street and ascending the stairs to their room.
text_phrases: walking slowly down the other side of the street
large blue envelope in his hand

130-160.description: Sherlock Holmes explains to Dr. Watson how he deduced that a man was a retired sergeant of Marines based on his observations.
text_phrases: great blue anchor tattooed on the back of the fellow’s hand

130-160.description: Sherlock Holmes and Dr. Watson receive a letter from Tobias Gregson about a mysterious death at Lauriston Gardens.
text_phrases: bad business during the night at 3, Lauriston Gardens
body of a gentleman, well dressed
marks of blood in the room

130-160.description: Holmes and Watson arrive at Lauriston Gardens to investigate the scene of the crime.
text_phrases: dun-coloured veil hung over the house-tops

161-184.description: Sherlock Holmes and Dr. Watson arrive at a crime scene where Holmes begins to inspect the surroundings and the body of the deceased. The room is stark, with a discolored ceiling and a grim atmosphere.
161-184.location: Dining room of a suburban London house
objects: vacant sightless eyes of the deceased
text_phrases: stump of a red wax candle
well brushed and trim top hat

161-184.scene_title: Holmes and Watson Meet Gregson and Lestrade
161-184.description: Upon arriving at the house, Holmes and Watson are greeted by detectives Gregson and Lestrade, who discuss the peculiarities of the case.
161-184.location: Entrance of a suburban London house

185-218.scene_title: The Examination of the Crime Scene
185-218.description: Detectives and Sherlock Holmes examine the crime scene, discussing the evidence found on the body and in the room, including a woman's wedding ring and a mysterious word written on the wall.
text_phrases: a ring tinkled down and rolled across the floor
a litter of objects upon one of the bottom steps of the stairs
Gold watch, No. 97163, by Barraud, of London
Gold Albert chain, very heavy and solid
Gold pin—bull-dog’s head, with rubies as eyes
Russian leather card-case, with cards of Enoch J. Drebber
Two letters—one addressed to E. J. Drebber and one to Joseph Stangerson
the paper had fallen away in parts
a large piece had peeled off, leaving a yellow square of coarse plastering
scrawled in blood-red letters a single word—RACHE
he whipped a tape measure and a large round magnifying glass from his pocket

219-241.scene_title: Holmes and Detectives Discuss the Case
219-241.description: Sherlock Holmes discusses the details of a murder case with detectives Gregson and Lestrade, providing them with insights and observations about the murderer.
text_phrases: genius is an infinite capacity for taking pains

219-241.scene_title: Holmes Deduces Details of the Murder
219-241.description: Sherlock Holmes provides a detailed deduction about the murderer's physical characteristics and actions to the detectives.
text_phrases: horse with three old shoes and one new one
finger-nails of his right hand were remarkably long

219-241.scene_title: Holmes and Watson Depart for Audley Court
219-241.description: Sherlock Holmes and Dr. Watson leave the residence to visit John Rance, following up on the murder investigation.

242-257.scene_title: Holmes and Watson Discuss the Case
242-257.description: Holmes and Watson are discussing the complexities of a mysterious case involving two men, a cabman, and a series of unexplained events.
text_phrases: My head is in a whirl
the more one thinks of it the more mysterious it grows
Holmes took a half-sovereign from his pocket and played with it pensively

242-257.description: Holmes and Watson arrive at Audley Court, a dreary and unattractive location, to meet Constable Rance.
text_phrases: Audley Court was not an attractive locality
The narrow passage led us into a quadrangle paved with flags
the door of which was decorated with a small slip of brass on which the name Rance was engraved

242-257.description: In a small front parlour, Constable Rance recounts the events of his night patrol, detailing a mysterious light in an empty house.
242-257.location: Front parlour at Number 46, Audley Court
text_phrases: we were shown into a little front parlour to await his coming
Rance sat down on the horsehair sofa
knitted his brows as though determined not to omit anything in his narrative
the constable answered with his eyes upon the little golden disk

258-287.scene_title: John Rance's Encounter at the House
258-287.description: John Rance describes his eerie experience at the house where he found a body, his interaction with a drunken man at the gate, and his conversation with Sherlock Holmes.
258-287.location: Inside a dimly lit room with a flickering candle

258-287.description: Sherlock Holmes and Dr. Watson leave the scene after Holmes deduces critical information about the drunken man and criticizes Rance's lack of observation.
text_phrases: we started off for the cab

258-287.scene_title: Holmes and Watson in the Cab
258-287.description: Holmes and Watson discuss the case and Holmes's plans to catch the suspect using the ring as bait while traveling back to their lodgings.

288-316.scene_title: Holmes and Watson Discuss the Case
288-316.description: Holmes and Watson discuss the Brixton Road affair over dinner, touching on topics from Darwin's views on music to the mysterious circumstances surrounding the case.
Holmes explains his plan to catch the man in the brown coat using a fake advertisement about a found wedding ring.
text_phrases: I have my old service revolver

288-316.description: Watson prepares his revolver as instructed by Holmes, while Holmes plays his violin, awaiting the arrival of the suspect.
text_phrases: Holmes was engaged in his favourite occupation of scraping upon his violin
Put your pistol in your pocket

317-337.description: An old woman, mistaken for a man of violence, enters Holmes and Watson's apartment, surprising them with her appearance and the story of her daughter's lost wedding ring.
text_phrases: a very old and wrinkled woman hobbled into the apartment
dazzled by the sudden blaze of light
bleared eyes and fumbling in her pocket

317-337.description: Sherlock Holmes decides to follow the old woman, suspecting her to be an accomplice in a larger scheme, and rushes out into the night.
317-337.location: Holmes and Watson's apartment, then London streets
text_phrases: Sherlock Holmes sprang to his feet
enveloped in an ulster and a cravat

317-337.description: Holmes returns home after an unsuccessful pursuit, revealing his failure to Watson with a mix of amusement and chagrin.

338-356.scene_title: Holmes and Watson Discuss the Case
338-356.description: Sherlock Holmes and Dr. Watson discuss the details of a mysterious case involving a disguised young man and the subsequent newspaper reports while seated at breakfast.
338-356.location: Holmes and Watson's residence, Baker Street, London
text_phrases: Sherlock Holmes and I read these notices over together at breakfast
the details of a mysterious case

338-356.scene_title: Arrival of the Baker Street Division
338-356.description: A group of unkempt street children, known as the Baker Street division of the detective police force, burst into Holmes and Watson's room under Holmes' command.
338-356.location: Holmes and Watson's residence, Baker Street, London
text_phrases: half a dozen of the dirtiest and most ragged street Arabs
He handed each of them a shilling

357-395.description: Detective Gregson arrives at Sherlock Holmes' residence, bursting with excitement to share his breakthrough in the Brixton case.
text_phrases: fair-haired detective came up the stairs
Take a seat, and try one of these cigars

357-395.description: Gregson explains to Holmes and Watson how he solved the case and captured Arthur Charpentier, while mocking Lestrade's incorrect pursuit.
text_phrases: slapped his thigh in a paroxysm of amusement
gone off upon the wrong track

357-395.description: Detective Gregson recounts his visit to Madame Charpentier, where he uncovers crucial information about Mr. Drebber's last moments from Madame and her daughter.
text_phrases: found her very pale and distressed
No good can ever come of falsehood, mother
Let us be frank with this gentleman

396-423.description: Mrs. Charpentier recounts the events leading to Mr. Drebber's departure and subsequent return, where he proposes to Alice in a drunken state, only to be interrupted by Arthur Charpentier.
text_phrases: Mr. Drebber has been with us
Copenhagen label upon each of their trunks
Mr. Drebber became very much the worse for drink
he caught her by the wrist
Arthur standing in the doorway laughing, with a stick in his hand

396-423.description: The aftermath of the scuffle is discussed, leading to the mysterious death of Mr. Drebber and the arrest of Arthur Charpentier based on his suspicious behavior and possession of a heavy stick.
text_phrases: concerned in the death of that scoundrel Drebber

424-444.description: Lestrade enters the room where Holmes, Gregson, and Watson are discussing the case, looking disheveled and troubled. He reveals that Joseph Stangerson has been murdered at Halliday's Private Hotel.
text_phrases: Gregson sprang out of his chair
remainder of his whiskey and water

424-444.description: Lestrade recounts his morning investigation at Halliday's Private Hotel where he discovers the murdered body of Joseph Stangerson, with a mysterious word written in blood above the corpse.
text_phrases: door was locked on the inside
body of a man in his nightdress
deep stab in the left side
word RACHE, written in letters of blood

445-466.scene_title: The Discovery of the Ladder and the Man
445-466.description: A milk boy notices a ladder against a hotel window and sees a man descending it, initially mistaking him for a carpenter.
445-466.location: Lane leading from the mews at the back of the hotel
text_phrases: A milk boy, passing on his way to the dairy
a ladder, which usually lay there, was raised against one of the windows of the second floor
saw a man descend the ladder

445-466.scene_title: Holmes and Lestrade Discuss the Clues
445-466.description: Sherlock Holmes and Inspector Lestrade discuss the lack of clues in the murder room, except for a novel, a pipe, and a telegram.
text_phrases: The man's novel, with which he had read himself to sleep was lying upon the bed
his pipe was on a chair beside him
a single telegram, dated from Cleveland

445-466.description: Holmes conducts an experiment with the pills found at the crime scene by dissolving one in water and giving it to a sick terrier to observe its effects.
text_phrases: I will now cut one of these pills in two
One half we return into the box for future purposes
The other half I will place in this wine glass, in which is a teaspoonful of water
add a little milk to make the mixture palatable, and on presenting it to the dog

467-476.description: Sherlock Holmes, after a moment of revelation, tests a pill on a terrier, which convulses and dies, confirming the pill's lethality.
text_phrases: cut the other pill in two

467-476.description: Sherlock Holmes is confronted by detectives Gregson and Lestrade about his knowledge of the assassin, leading to a tense discussion about the case.
text_phrases: walk up and down the room

477-491.description: Sherlock Holmes captures Jefferson Hope using handcuffs disguised as a buckle while pretending to need help with his luggage.
text_phrases: pinioned his feet as well as his hands

477-491.description: A vast, barren landscape of the American West, described as a land of desolation and silence, inhabited only by occasional wildlife and scattered remains.
477-491.location: American West, from Sierra Nevada to Nebraska
text_phrases: bones: some large and coarse, others smaller and more delicate

492-515.scene_title: The Lonely Traveller and the Child
492-515.description: A gaunt, elderly man and a small girl are stranded on a barren landscape, surrounded by a vast salt plain and distant mountains. The man, appearing weak and haggard, has just set down a heavy bundle from which a little girl emerges. They discuss their dire situation with a mix of despair and childlike hope.
text_phrases: long, brown hair and beard flecked and dashed with white

516-536.description: A little girl and a man kneel on a shawl in a barren landscape, praying together under a clear sky before falling asleep beside a boulder.
text_phrases: Side by side on the narrow shawl knelt the two wanderers
Her chubby face, and his haggard, angular visage were both turned up to the cloudless heaven
the man’s grizzled beard was mixed with the gold tresses of his companion

516-536.description: A vast caravan of waggons, horsemen, and people stretches across the plain, approaching the bluff where the two characters are sleeping.
516-536.location: Alkali plain near the Sierra Blanco
text_phrases: the canvas-covered tilts of waggons and the figures of armed horsemen began to show up through the haze
Right across the enormous plain stretched the straggling array, waggons and carts, men on horseback, and men on foot
Innumerable women who staggered along under burdens, and children who toddled beside the waggons or peeped out from under the white coverings

516-536.description: A group of scouts from the caravan climb a rugged crag, reacting in astonishment upon discovering a pink wisp fluttering from its summit.
text_phrases: From its summit there fluttered a little wisp of pink, showing up hard and bright against the grey rocks behind
The watchers from the plain below could see them flit from rock to rock until their figures stood out against the skyline
Suddenly his followers saw him throw up his hands, as though overcome with astonishment

537-555.description: A tall, thin man and a small child awaken on a barren hill, surrounded by buzzards, as a large group of people approach them.
John Ferrier and the child are rescued by a large group of Mormons and introduced to their beliefs as they are led to a large, ornate wagon.
text_phrases: enormous body of men and of beasts
gaudiness and smartness of its appearance

537-555.description: The caravan of Mormons, along with John and Lucy Ferrier, begins its journey towards Zion, emphasizing their communal belief and unity.
text_phrases: Elder to whose care the two waifs had been committed

556-562.description: The Mormon immigrants, led by their leader, arrive in the broad valley of Utah, seeing it bathed in sunlight and learning that this fertile land is to be theirs forever.
text_phrases: broad valley of Utah bathed in the sunlight

556-562.description: The Mormons, under the leadership of Young, begin the construction of their new city with farms, streets, and a great temple, working from dawn till dusk.
John Ferrier builds a substantial log-house on his newly acquired farm, which over the years grows into a roomy villa.
Lucy Ferrier grows up strong and healthy, becoming a beloved figure in her community as she helps her father on the farm and rides her mustang.
text_phrases: lithe girlish figure tripping through the wheatfields

563-576.description: Lucy Ferrier rides skillfully through a bustling scene of migrants and animals, only to be trapped among a herd of cattle. A mysterious young man comes to her aid.
text_phrases: long chestnut hair floating out behind
long rifle slung over his shoulders

563-576.description: After rescuing Lucy, Jefferson Hope reveals his identity and hints at a past connection with her father, sparking a new friendship.
text_phrases: long rifle slung over his shoulders

577-590.description: Jefferson Hope bids farewell to Lucy at the farm gate, promising to return and claim her in two months. He then gallops away on his horse, leaving Lucy at the gate.
text_phrases: He came galloping down the road
He threw the bridle over the fence
taking her two hands in his
gazing tenderly down into her face
She stood at the gate, gazing after him

577-590.description: After Jefferson Hope's departure, Lucy walks back into the house, overwhelmed with emotions, now the happiest girl in Utah.
text_phrases: She walked back into the house
the happiest girl in all Utah

577-590.description: John Ferrier reflects on the impending loss of his adopted daughter to Jefferson Hope, feeling conflicted yet reconciled by her happiness.
text_phrases: John Ferrier’s heart was sore within him
the impending loss of his adopted child
her bright and happy face reconciled him

591-615.description: John Ferrier is startled by the visit of Brigham Young, the Mormon leader, who confronts him about his faith and his daughter's future.
After Brigham Young leaves, John Ferrier reflects on the difficult situation regarding his daughter's marriage choices as she approaches him, having overheard the conversation.
text_phrases: heavy step scrunching along the shingly path
soft hand was laid upon his
broad, rough hand caressingly over her chestnut hair

616-645.scene_title: John Ferrier's Confrontation with the Young Mormons
616-645.description: John Ferrier confronts two young Mormons, Joseph Stangerson and the son of Elder Drebber, who have come to solicit his daughter's hand in marriage. The confrontation escalates, leading to Ferrier angrily ordering them out.
text_phrases: feet cocked up upon the stove
standing in front of the window
riding-whip from the backs of his two visitors

616-645.description: John Ferrier, after a tense discussion about their safety and future plans, takes precautions by securing the doors and preparing his shotgun, indicating his fear of impending danger.
text_phrases: cleaned and loaded the rusty old shotgun
hung upon the wall of his bedroom

646-655.description: John Ferrier discovers a threatening message pinned to his bed coverlet, warning him of a limited time for amendment.
text_phrases: a small square of paper pinned on to the coverlet of his bed
Twenty-nine days are given you for amendment, and then——

646-655.description: Each morning, John Ferrier finds a new number marked in his house, counting down the days left, causing him increasing dread.
text_phrases: In the centre of the ceiling was scrawled, with a burned stick apparently, the number 28
a great 27 had been painted upon the outside of his door

646-655.description: On the eve of the last day, John Ferrier hears a mysterious tapping at the door, heightening his fear of the impending threat.
text_phrases: tapping very gently upon one of the panels of the door

646-655.description: After opening the door to confront his fears, John Ferrier finds a man lying on the ground, adding to the mystery.
646-655.location: Front garden of John Ferrier's house
text_phrases: a man lying flat upon his face upon the ground
the little front garden lay before the farmer’s eyes

656-677.description: Jefferson Hope, appearing haggard and desperate, enters John Ferrier's house, startling him. He immediately asks for food and devours the leftovers on the table.
text_phrases: he leaned up against the wall
fierce face and resolute expression of Jefferson Hope
cold meat and bread which were still lying upon the table

656-677.description: Jefferson Hope discusses the urgent need to escape with John Ferrier, detailing the preparations and the dangers surrounding them.
text_phrases: I have a mule and two horses waiting in the Eagle Ravine
Two thousand dollars in gold, and five in notes
We must push for Carson City through the mountains

656-677.description: Jefferson Hope, John Ferrier, and Lucy Ferrier make a stealthy escape from their house through a side window, moving cautiously across the fields under the cover of darkness.
text_phrases: Opening the window very slowly and carefully
gained the shelter of the hedge
dragged them down into the shadow

656-677.description: After escaping the house, Jefferson Hope and his companions overhear a secret meeting between shadowy figures in the fields, discussing plans and signals.
text_phrases: melancholy hooting of a mountain owl
vague shadowy figure emerged from the gap
When the Whip-poor-Will calls three times

678-692.description: Jefferson Hope, along with the girl and old Ferrier, navigate through a rugged and narrow footpath leading to the mountains to escape their pursuers. The path is perilous, surrounded by dark jagged peaks and a dried-up watercourse.
The fugitives encounter a solitary sentinel on a rock who challenges them as they try to pass through the mountain pass. After a brief exchange of countersigns, they are allowed to proceed.
As dawn breaks, the fugitives are surrounded by the breathtaking view of snow-capped peaks and steep rocky banks, providing a moment of awe and respite from their perilous journey.
The fugitives make a temporary camp in a sheltered nook, where Jefferson Hope starts a fire for warmth and sets out to hunt for food, leaving the old man and the girl by the fire.

693-699.description: A hunter in a mountainous region spots a big-horn sheep and takes a shot, causing the animal to fall into the valley below.
text_phrases: rested his rifle upon a rock

693-699.description: The hunter realizes he is lost in the mountains as night falls, struggling to find his way back.
text_phrases: valley divided and sub-divided into many gorges

693-699.scene_title: Return to Camp and Discovery of Disaster
693-699.description: The hunter returns to his camp only to find it deserted and a grave indicating a disaster has occurred.
text_phrases: sheet of paper stuck in the cleft fork

700-714.scene_title: Jefferson Hope's Resolve by the Fire
700-714.description: Jefferson Hope, feeling despair, decides to devote his life to seeking revenge. He stands by a desolate fire, cooking food and preparing for his journey of vengeance.
text_phrases: cooked enough to last him for a few days

700-714.description: Jefferson Hope, now a tattered and unkempt wanderer, encounters a Mormon named Cowper in the Eagle Cañon and inquires about Lucy Ferrier's fate.
Jefferson Hope enters a room where Lucy Ferrier's body lies, kisses her forehead, removes her wedding ring, and disappears into the night.
text_phrases: pressed his lips reverently to her cold forehead
took the wedding-ring from her finger

715-720.description: Jefferson Hope lingers in the mountains, nursing his vengeance while leading a wild life.
text_phrases: nursing in his heart the fierce desire for vengeance

715-720.description: Jefferson Hope makes attempts on the lives of Stangerson and Drebber, narrowly missing them with a bullet and a boulder.
Jefferson Hope returns to the old Nevada mines to recuperate and gather resources for his continued quest for vengeance.
text_phrases: returned to the old Nevada mines

715-720.description: Jefferson Hope travels from town to town across the United States, searching for Drebber and Stangerson.
715-720.location: Various towns across the United States

715-720.description: Jefferson Hope is recognized and captured in Cleveland after Drebber spots him and senses danger.
text_phrases: glance of a face in a window
Jefferson Hope was taken into custody

721-742.description: Holmes loosens the towel bound around the prisoner's ankles, allowing him to stretch his legs and stand freely.
721-742.location: Small chamber at the police station
text_phrases: Holmes at once took the prisoner at his word
loosened the towel which we had bound round his ankles

721-742.scene_title: Cab Ride to the Police Station
721-742.description: The group, including the prisoner, descends and enters a cab. Lestrade drives them to the police station.
text_phrases: Lestrade mounted the box, whipped up the horse

721-742.description: The prisoner is booked at the police station, where an inspector notes down his details and informs him of his rights.
text_phrases: police Inspector noted down our prisoner’s name

721-742.description: Jefferson Hope reveals his medical condition to Dr. Watson, who diagnoses him with an aortic aneurism.
Jefferson Hope starts recounting his story, explaining his motives and actions leading to the crime.

743-749.description: The narrator describes his efforts to follow and keep tabs on Drebber and Stangerson in London, detailing his tactics and the challenges he faces.
text_phrases: Driving and riding are as natural to me as walking
I applied at a cabowner’s office
I had a map beside me

743-749.description: The narrator follows Drebber and Stangerson to Euston Station, overhearing their conversation and plans, and prepares for his moment of vengeance.
text_phrases: I left a boy to hold my horse
followed them on to the platform
Drebber said that he had a little business of his own to do
if he missed the last train he should rejoin him at Halliday’s Private Hotel

743-749.description: The narrator describes how he managed to make a duplicate key to a house in Brixton Road, planning to lure Drebber there.
text_phrases: a gentleman who had been engaged in looking over some houses in the Brixton Road had dropped the key of one of them in my carriage
I had taken a moulding of it

750-761.scene_title: The Confrontation in the Brixton Road House
750-761.description: The scene describes a tense and dramatic confrontation between the narrator and Enoch Drebber in a dark, rainy setting. The narrator has led a drunken Drebber into a house, where he reveals his identity and confronts him with past grievances, leading to Drebber's horrified realization.
text_phrases: wild, bleak night, blowing hard and raining in torrents
Drebber all huddled together in a drunken sleep
putting it to a wax candle
holding the light to my own face
perspiration break out upon his brow
leaned my back against the door

762-771.scene_title: Confrontation and Death of Enoch Drebber
762-771.description: The narrator confronts Enoch Drebber, accusing him of past crimes and forcing him to choose between two pills, one of which is poisoned. After Drebber makes his choice, he dies from the poison.
text_phrases: shaking the key in his face
drew my knife and held it to his throat
held Lucy’s marriage ring in front of his eyes

762-771.description: After the death of Enoch Drebber, the narrator uses his own blood to write the word 'RACHE' on the wall, intending to mislead the police.
text_phrases: The blood had been streaming from my nose
dipped my finger in my own blood and printed it on a convenient place on the wall

762-771.description: The narrator returns to the crime scene to retrieve Lucy's marriage ring, which he had lost, and encounters a police officer.
text_phrases: I might have dropped it when I stooped over Drebber’s body
walked right into the arms of a police-officer

762-771.description: The narrator breaks into Stangerson's room and confronts him, leading to a struggle where Stangerson is fatally stabbed.
762-771.location: Stangerson's bedroom at Halliday's Private Hotel
text_phrases: ladders which were lying in the lane
made my way into his room

762-771.description: Jefferson Hope is tricked into going to 221B Baker Street, where he is arrested by a young man.
text_phrases: his cab was wanted by a gentleman at 221B, Baker Street
the next thing I knew, this young man here had the bracelets on my wrists

772-789.description: Sherlock Holmes questions a prisoner about his accomplice related to a ring, while the Inspector discusses legal formalities regarding the prisoner's upcoming court appearance.
text_phrases: the prisoner will be brought before the magistrates
Jefferson Hope was led off by a couple of warders

772-789.description: Holmes and Watson discuss the implications of Jefferson Hope's death and the nature of their investigation.
text_phrases: Holmes remarked, as we chatted it over next evening
I would not have missed the investigation for anything
Simple as it was, there were several most instructive points about it

772-789.description: Sherlock Holmes arrives at a house, examines the roadway and garden path for clues, and deduces the characteristics of the nocturnal visitors.
text_phrases: walked slowly down the garden path
the heavy footmarks of the constables

790-798.description: Sherlock Holmes deduces the motive behind the murder of Mr. Drebber, considering various possibilities such as robbery, politics, and personal reasons. He examines the crime scene, finding clues like a ring and an inscription that lead him to conclude the murder was due to a personal vendetta.
text_phrases: the great question as to the reason why
Robbery had not been the object of the murder
Was it politics, then, or was it a woman?
the inscription was discovered upon the wall

790-798.description: Sherlock Holmes continues his investigation by sending a telegram to Cleveland police regarding Mr. Drebber’s past, specifically about any issues related to marriage. He deduces that the cab driver must be the murderer and organizes a group of street kids to find the suspect among London's cab drivers.
text_phrases: telegraphed to the head of the police at Cleveland
limiting my enquiry to the circumstances connected with the marriage of Enoch Drebber
organized my Street Arab detective corps
sent them systematically to every cab proprietor in London

790-798.description: Sherlock Holmes discusses the capture of the murderer, Jefferson Hope, and the unexpected incident of Mr. Stangerson's murder. He reflects on the chain of events and logical deductions that led to the resolution of the case. Holmes and Watson consider publishing an account of the case.
text_phrases: The murder of Stangerson was an incident which was entirely unexpected
came into possession of the pills
the whole thing is a chain of logical sequences
Your merits should be publicly recognized
You should publish an account of the case

799-801.description: Sherlock Holmes and Dr. John Watson are in their shared living room at 221B Baker Street. Holmes, with a laugh, remarks on the outcome of their investigation, referring to it as 'Study in Scarlet'. Watson, not entirely convinced but still content, mentions his journal where he has recorded all the facts, ensuring that the public will be informed.
text_phrases: cried Sherlock Holmes with a laugh
I have all the facts in my journal
make yourself contented by the consciousness of success
